title: From which source (some Eastern teachings, stoicism…?) was Nietzsche inspired when he used “Amor Fati”? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my reading — Amor Fati, which means, ‘love of one’s fate,’ or ‘embracing the Now,’ or ‘accepting yourself exactly as you are,’ was Nietzsche’s version of Stoicism. Roman Stoicism taught how to ‘live in harmony with Nature,’ in the sense of accepting the hand that Nature gave us, including poverty, privation, the elements and even hunting for food. These are the qualities of the good soldier. I believe that young Friedrich Nietzsche was profoundly influenced by his experiences in the Franco-Prussian War. He was 4F because of his frailty and eyesight, but he was conscripted to work on the battlefield as a transporter of the wounded to the hospital. He was therefore accepted by the soldiers as a regular guy, and he fell in love with them. They were majestic — proud, young, life-affirming, strong, and they made their own rules of life. Nobody told them what to do — they did their duty as it spoke to their hearts. They followed their captain with genuine respect and admiration. It broke Nietzsche’s heart to see some of them at the end of a battle dead, or severely wounded and screaming. After a few experiences like this, Nietzsche fainted off his horse and was relieved of duty forever. Yet I believe Nietzsche never forgot his few months as a soldier. He proudly wore his uniform. It was these young Prussian soldiers who “seized the day.” They were his exemplars of Amor Fati.

“Culture,” is for Nietzsche inseparable from education; his primary concern is with the attainment of culture. And the “Dionysian faith,” amor fati, is—according to Nietzsche—the state of mind that accompanies such culture as he envisages. It is the faith of those who are above any ressentiment because they affirm not only their own being but also all existence, the faith of Spinoza and Goethe. “To educate educators! But the first ones must educate theselves! And for these I write” [VII, 215]. To educate educators—that might have been Stefan George’s motto; yet the poet and his Circle failed to understand Nietzsche’s own “education” beyond his break with Wagner, which, as we have seen, they construed as “apostasy” —and George himself became “the Master,” like Wagner. This is overlooked when George (and Spengler) are pictured as mediators between Nietzsche and the National Socialists. George influenced National Socialism precisely where he differed from Nietzsche. (And this is also true of Spengler.) Inasmuch as the George Kreis evolved a Fuhrerprinzip and a party line, it stood opposed to Nietzsche’s heritage—quite consciously and deliberately opposed to it, as George’s previously cited poem on “Nietzsche” shows: Nietzsche’s Socratic protestantism and chronic heresy, so utterly irreconcilable with any form of totalitariansim, were rejected in favor of “constraint with a circle.”
